title: Hotelplan still in the black despite adverse conditions
text:
Save 
The company behind winter sports specialists such as Inghams and Ski Total has blamed bad weather and the government’s legislation on school holidays for a difficult year. 
Hotelplan Ltd saw its pre-tax profits almost halve to £1.9m. This came in spite of a 4% rise in turnover to £188.6m. 
Accounts released recently at Companies House cover winter 2013-14 as well as the following summer up to October 31, 2014. 
The company said that sales for ski holidays had been hit by “the late arrival of snow” in European resorts, plus storms and floods in the UK, which “disrupted the selling environment still further”. 
Speaking to TTG, Andy Perrin, Hotelplan chief executive, said: “It was a tough year, we had poor snow at the beginning of the season and the floods that hit the UK happened at the worst possible time for the ski market. 
“The floods came that Christmas and didn’t go until half-term, which is the heart and soul of the selling season.” 
Hotelplan also pointed the finger at the government for legislation that removed the “discretion of head teachers over permitting holidays during the term time”. 
The late Easter also compounded “an already difficult season”. 
Summer 2014 also proved difficult with “overcapacity in the wider market and especially the ever-increasing growth in heavily discounted cruising holidays” causing the problems, according to Hotelplan. 
Hotelplan’s bad year was made worse by a £0.8m provision for historic overseas taxes. 
“Despite growing passenger volumes and average selling prices, the challenging trading conditions saw margins come under pressure…” the company said in its strategic report. 
However, Perrin added despite the problems he was proud to see the operator still record a profit for the period. 
He said, having weathered the storm, the company is now well-placed going forward, adding: “We’ve bounced back and 2015 is looking really good. 
“We’re actually back out in the market place and we’re looking at acquisitions. We’re having a really good year, business is strong and bookings are holding up.” 
Subsidiary Inntravel, which bills itself as a “slow holidays” specialist, enjoyed a better year. 
Turnover rose by 5% to £15.5m, helping boost operating profit by 14% to £1.8m. 
“The company delivered a successful financial year with all of the core programme achieving turnover growth, and the company saw a substantial increase in bookings received from customers based overseas (especially the US and Australia),” the company said. 
Inghams, Inntravel and the rest of the UK brands are ultimately owned by Swiss retail cooperative Migros. 
Inntravel was bought by Hotelplan UK from Amber Travel in 2008 while the Enigma Travel Group, comprising Esprit Ski, Esprit Sun, Ski Total and Santa’s Lapland, was purchased in 2010.
